Incidents.Name: Eagle Fire
Incidents.Location: Los Coyotes Indian Reservation, Warner Springs
Incidents.ConditionStatement:
CAL FIRE Incident Command Team 10 has transfered the fire back to Unit today.
Remaining fire crews will continue suppression repair, mop-up and patrol of the fire perimeter. In conjunction with the Bureau of Indian Affairs and California State Parks and Recreation, a CAL FIRE Suppression Repair Team is working to mitigate the effects of fire control activities and prepare for potential erosion due to forecasted precipitation. Demobilization of firefighting resources continues. The Borrego Palm Canyon Campground and the Lost Valley Boy Scout Camp have re-opened. For additional information regarding Anza Borrego Desert State Park Camping and Trail impacts, please contact California State Parks and Recreation.
Incidents.SearchDescription: The Eagle Fire started on July 21, 2011 near the LOS COYOTES INDIAN RESERVATION, WARNER SPRINGS and burned 14,100 acres

Incidents.Location: Community of Big Pine
Incidents.ConditionStatement:
Firefighters remain at scene to mop up and patrol for hot spots. Rain continues to fall in the fire area.

There is no impact to Highway 395.

The American Red Cross is offering assistance to the victims whose homes were damaged or destroyed by the fire and will be holding a meeting today at 10 a.m. at the Big Pine School to discuss disaster assistance.

Despite the extreme winds, firefighters were able to quickly contain this fire due to the work and cooperation between the volunteer, state, local and federal firefighters, we well as the law enforcement agencies and public works departments.

Incidents.Name: Tulare County Lightning Fires
Incidents.Location: Throughout the Tulare County foothills
Incidents.ConditionStatement:
Over 470 confirmed lighting strikes since Friday afternoon. ​The largest of these fires was located northwest of Woodlake on Ave 376 and Road 197 known as the “Mud Springs Gap” area. Fire fighting personnel continue to suppress the 343 acre fire which was 100% contained.

​A second fire in the same area (Ave 376 / Road 212) was limited to 40 acres and was 100% contained by 8 a.m. Saturday morning.  Both of these fires which were reported at 9:45 pm Friday were caused by lighting strikes.

​By Saturday morning another fire (Gordon Fire ) was located off Yokohl Dr east of Exeter.  Resources had stopped the forward progress of this fire by 10:00 am . This fire was held to just under 10 acres. Fire Fighting crews remained throughout the day to gain full containment.
Incidents.SearchDescription: The Tulare County Lightning Fires burned in Sept 2011 near Throughout the Tulare County foothills,Tulare County.

No homes were threatened by the fire, as it burned mainly in open grass and brush on land owned by the UC Field Research Station. Fire investigators were able to determine that the fire was sparked by a downed powerline.

Incidents.Name: San Diego County Lightning Fires
Incidents.Location: Boulevard, Sunshine Summit and throughout backcountry of San Diego County
Incidents.ConditionStatement:
CAL FIRE responded to several lightning caused fires in the backcountry of San Diego County.

The Chihuahua Fire, off of Chihuahua Valley Road near the community of Sunshine Summit, is now 100% contained at 40 acres. There are no structures threatened. Full containment of the fire is expected later today. The fire was reported at 4:22 p.m.

The Border Fire, off of Tierra Real Lane near the community of Boulevard, was 100% contained at 15 acres on Friday. The fire was originally reported at 4:24 p.m.

The Cain Fire, north of the Manzanita Indian Reservation was 100% contained at 1 acre on Friday. There were no structures threatened and the fire was reported at 2:33 p.m.

The Lucky Fire, off of Sunrise Highway in Mt. Laguna was 100% contained at 1/4 acre Friday. There were no structures threatened and the fire was reported at 3:02 p.m.
Incidents.SearchDescription: The San Diego County Lightning Fires burned in Oct 2011 near Boulevard, Sunshine Summit and throughout backcountry of San Diego County.

Incidents.ConditionStatement:
9/15 AM - Approximately 450 lightning strikes in northern California
No new lightning fires reported on State responsibility
27 new reported lightning caused fires on Federal responsibility

9/14 AM - 3,200 lightning strikes in the past 24 hours has resulted in 14 new fires for a running total of 108 new fires.

9/13 PM - 94 lightning sparked fires since 9/9. Largest fire was contained at 15 acres.

9/13 AM - The past 24 hours northern California has received over 6000 lightning strikes. There have been 62 lightning sparked fires since 9/9.

9/12 - 31 state fires reported due to lightning in the last 24 hour period.
Lassen-Modoc Unit - 7 fires - largest being 5 acres - 100% contained.
Nevada-Yuba-Placer Unit - 4 single tree fires - 100% contained.
Shasta-Trinity Unit - 3 fires - 100% contained.

7 confirmed fires on Federal Responsibility yesterday, all less than an acre.
Santa Clara Unit (Contra Costa County) 1 fire - 6 acres near Mt. Diablo - 100% contained.

Incidents.Name: California Tsunami
Incidents.Location: California Coast
Incidents.ConditionStatement:
Following a magnitude 9.0 earthquake that slammed Japan's northeastern coast, a Tsunami Warning was issued for the California coast. That warning has been cancelled.

CAL FIRE crews were actively engaged in tsunami response and assisting with evacuations throughout the Coast. CAL FIRE provides fire services through cooperative agreements with departments affected including the San Luis Obispo County Fire, Santa Cruz County Fire, Pismo Beach Fire, Coastside Fire Protection District (Half Moon Bay). In many of the Coastal areas CAL FIRE held personnel on duty, increased staffing, as well as put its swift water rescue teams, helicopters and fire crews all on stand by.

Public Warning
Residents and visitors are advised to remain vigilant and cautious around the water. Even though underwater currents and riptides have diminished, they are still being registered on tidal gauges up and down the coast, though less frequently and less powerful than previously measured.

Humboldt/Del Norte County
The Humboldt/Del Norte area was hit by multiple surges of water throughout the day with extensive damage reported particularly in Crescent City. CAL FIRE assisted Crescent City and Arcadia Fire Districts with several fire engines, as well as having a helicopter assigned for possible rescue operations.

Santa Cruz County
CAL FIRE / Santa Cruz County Fire Department assisted with the evacuation of the community of Pajaro Dunes. That evacuation order was lifted Friday afternoon. Fire resources spent most of yesterday patrolling areas along the coast for impacts and pre-planning for emergencies.

San Luis Obispo County
CAL FIRE assisted law enforcement agencies to evacuated approximately 1,800 residents from low lying coastal communities. Those evacuation orders were lifted Friday afternoon. At the peak CAL FIRE / San Luis Obispo County Fire had 23 fire resources assigned to patrolling and responding to tsunami related incidents, as well as working in the County’s Emergency Operation Center in preplanning for increased emergency impacts. The Diablo Canyon Power Plant status identified an “Unusual Event” due to the precautionary road closure and evacuation of the community of Avila Beach.

San Mateo County
CAL FIRE / San Mateo County Fire Department resources spent most of yesterday patrolling coastal areas.

Sonoma County
CAL FIRE / Sea Ranch Fire Department resources spent most of yesterday patrolling coastal areas.

ListIncidents.Name: Center Fire
ListIncidents.Location: Community of Big Pine
ListIncidents.ConditionStatement:
Firefighters remain at scene to mop up and patrol for hot spots. Rain continues to fall in the fire area.

There is no impact to Highway 395.

The American Red Cross is offering assistance to the victims whose homes were damaged or destroyed by the fire and will be holding a meeting today at 10 a.m. at the Big Pine School to discuss disaster assistance.

Despite the extreme winds, firefighters were able to quickly contain this fire due to the work and cooperation between the volunteer, state, local and federal firefighters, we well as the law enforcement agencies and public works departments.

ListIncidents.Name: Canyon Fire
ListIncidents.Location: Hwy 180 and Porter west of Squaw Valley, 8 miles east of Sangor
ListIncidents.ConditionStatement:
When firefighters arrived the fire was burning in dense annual grass at the end of Porter north of Hwy 180. The fire was burning in an area that was difficult to access by fire engines, however once an access point was made Bulldozers and hand crews assisted with battling the fire.
Two Southern California Edison 220 KV transmission lines were threatened early in the incident.Firefighters will continue their mop up efforts tonight. They expect to have full control of the fire Tuesday morning.

ListIncidents.Name: Krista Fire
ListIncidents.Location: north of Smartsville on the north side of the Yuba River
ListIncidents.ConditionStatement:
Today firefighters will continue mopping up and putting out any hot spots around the fire. Yesterday, a firing operation occured to secure additional areas around the perimeter and to burn out islands of unburned fuel inside the containment lines.

No homes were threatened by the fire, as it burned mainly in open grass and brush on land owned by the UC Field Research Station. Fire investigators were able to determine that the fire was sparked by a downed powerline.

ListIncidents.Name: Eagle Fire
ListIncidents.Location: Los Coyotes Indian Reservation, Warner Springs
ListIncidents.ConditionStatement:
CAL FIRE Incident Command Team 10 has transfered the fire back to Unit today.
Remaining fire crews will continue suppression repair, mop-up and patrol of the fire perimeter. In conjunction with the Bureau of Indian Affairs and California State Parks and Recreation, a CAL FIRE Suppression Repair Team is working to mitigate the effects of fire control activities and prepare for potential erosion due to forecasted precipitation. Demobilization of firefighting resources continues. The Borrego Palm Canyon Campground and the Lost Valley Boy Scout Camp have re-opened. For additional information regarding Anza Borrego Desert State Park Camping and Trail impacts, please contact California State Parks and Recreation.
ListIncidents.SearchDescription: The Eagle Fire started on July 21, 2011 near the LOS COYOTES INDIAN RESERVATION, WARNER SPRINGS and burned 14,100 acres

ListIncidents.Name: MMU Lightning Complex
ListIncidents.Location: Throughout Madera & Mariposa Counties
ListIncidents.ConditionStatement:
Multiple lightning strikes have occured throughout Madera & Mariposa Counties with minimal rainfall. As a result 16 confirmed fires have sparked in CAL FIRE's jurisdiction. All of the fires were in remote areas with difficult terrain and access for crews. Forward progress of all fires has been stopped.

Madera County
Bailey Fire
19 acres - 100% contained.

Hensley Fire
95 acres - 100% contained
located off Rd 400 below the Lake Hensley dam, northeast of Madera.

Mariposa County Grove Fire
10 acres - 100% contained

Silver Fire
3 acres - 100% contained
ListIncidents.SearchDescription: The MMU Lightning Complex started on July 31, 2011 and consisted of 16 fires for 129 acres.

ListIncidents.Name: Northern Region Lightning
ListIncidents.Location: Across northern California
ListIncidents.ConditionStatement:
9/15 AM - Approximately 450 lightning strikes in northern California
No new lightning fires reported on State responsibility
27 new reported lightning caused fires on Federal responsibility

9/14 AM - 3,200 lightning strikes in the past 24 hours has resulted in 14 new fires for a running total of 108 new fires.

9/13 PM - 94 lightning sparked fires since 9/9. Largest fire was contained at 15 acres.

9/13 AM - The past 24 hours northern California has received over 6000 lightning strikes. There have been 62 lightning sparked fires since 9/9.

9/12 - 31 state fires reported due to lightning in the last 24 hour period.
Lassen-Modoc Unit - 7 fires - largest being 5 acres - 100% contained.
Nevada-Yuba-Placer Unit - 4 single tree fires - 100% contained.
Shasta-Trinity Unit - 3 fires - 100% contained.
Tehama-Glenn Unit - 4 fires for a total of 3 acres - 100% contained.
Amador-El Dorado Unit - 13 fires, all less than half acre - 100% contained.

9/10 - A total of 517 lightning strikes in northern California yesterday, for a total of approximately 854 strikes in northern California since 9/7/11.
7 confirmed fires on Federal Responsibility yesterday, all less than an acre.
Santa Clara Unit (Contra Costa County) 1 fire - 6 acres near Mt. Diablo - 100% contained.
Nevada-Yuba-Placer Unit - 3 single tree fires - 100% contained.

9/9 - Approximately 50 total lightning strikes occurred in northern California.
Humboldt Unit - 1 small spot fire – 100% contained.
Santa Clara Unit (Contra Costa & Alameda Counties) - 5 fires with the largest at 15 acres, all 100% contained.
ListIncidents.SearchDescription: The Northern Region Lightning burned in Sept 2011 near Across northern California,Multiple Counties.
ListIncidents.SearchKeywords: Northern Region Lightning, September 2011, lightning

ListIncidents.Name: Tulare County Lightning Fires
ListIncidents.Location: Throughout the Tulare County foothills
ListIncidents.ConditionStatement:
Over 470 confirmed lighting strikes since Friday afternoon. ​The largest of these fires was located northwest of Woodlake on Ave 376 and Road 197 known as the “Mud Springs Gap” area. Fire fighting personnel continue to suppress the 343 acre fire which was 100% contained.

​A second fire in the same area (Ave 376 / Road 212) was limited to 40 acres and was 100% contained by 8 a.m. Saturday morning.  Both of these fires which were reported at 9:45 pm Friday were caused by lighting strikes.

​By Saturday morning another fire (Gordon Fire ) was located off Yokohl Dr east of Exeter.  Resources had stopped the forward progress of this fire by 10:00 am . This fire was held to just under 10 acres. Fire Fighting crews remained throughout the day to gain full containment.
ListIncidents.SearchDescription: The Tulare County Lightning Fires burned in Sept 2011 near Throughout the Tulare County foothills,Tulare County.

ListIncidents.Name: San Diego County Lightning Fires
ListIncidents.Location: Boulevard, Sunshine Summit and throughout backcountry of San Diego County
ListIncidents.ConditionStatement:
CAL FIRE responded to several lightning caused fires in the backcountry of San Diego County.

The Chihuahua Fire, off of Chihuahua Valley Road near the community of Sunshine Summit, is now 100% contained at 40 acres. There are no structures threatened. Full containment of the fire is expected later today. The fire was reported at 4:22 p.m.

The Border Fire, off of Tierra Real Lane near the community of Boulevard, was 100% contained at 15 acres on Friday. The fire was originally reported at 4:24 p.m.

The Cain Fire, north of the Manzanita Indian Reservation was 100% contained at 1 acre on Friday. There were no structures threatened and the fire was reported at 2:33 p.m.

The Lucky Fire, off of Sunrise Highway in Mt. Laguna was 100% contained at 1/4 acre Friday. There were no structures threatened and the fire was reported at 3:02 p.m.
ListIncidents.SearchDescription: The San Diego County Lightning Fires burned in Oct 2011 near Boulevard, Sunshine Summit and throughout backcountry of San Diego County.
ListIncidents.SearchKeywords: San Diego County lightning fires, lightning, October 2011, September 2011, San Diego County
